title: 114_hr2003
content: The Act is titled the "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" and it pertains to the distribution of death information by the Social Security Administration. The "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" amends Section 205(r) of the Social Security Act to require the Commissioner of Social Security to transmit information on deceased individuals to ensure completeness, timeliness, and accuracy. This information can be used by federal and state agencies administering benefits programs, with safeguards in place to protect unauthorized use or disclosure. The Commissioner of Social Security is required to provide information on deceased individuals to federal agencies for proper payment of benefits, with reimbursement for associated costs. This information can be used for various purposes through cooperative arrangements. The agency can use the Do Not Pay working system to compare death information with personally identifiable information for proper payments. It can also ensure proper payments under federal programs, carry out tax administration or debt collection duties, and provide information to policing agencies for prevention purposes. The Commissioner of Social Security can enter into arrangements with States to provide information on deceased individuals for specific purposes, such as state-funded programs or retirement systems. Safeguards are in place to protect the information from unauthorized use. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with States for specific purposes, with safeguards in place to protect against unauthorized use. Amendments to the Social Security Act and the Internal Revenue Code are outlined for statistical purposes and research activities. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to replace references to the Secretary of Health and Human Services with the Commissioner of Social Security. Additionally, a report to Congress on alternative sources of death data maintained by non-Federal sources is required, including an analysis of the accuracy and completeness of such data. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a report to Congress on the review and analysis of death data, including accuracy, interoperability, accessibility, cost, security, and reliability. The report will also compare potential alternate sources of death data to that distributed by the Commissioner of Social Security. Social Security benefits provided beyond the repeal date specified in the amendments. SEC. 7 of the Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012 amends the use of death data by government agencies. SEC. 7 of the Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012 requires the Office of Management and Budget to issue guidance to agencies within 6 months for improved data matching with death databases. The Office of Management and Budget is tasked with developing a plan to help states, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations provide death records electronically to the Federal Government. This plan may include recommendations for statutory changes or financial assistance. Additionally, a report to Congress on improving data matching for payments to deceased individuals is required within 270 days of the enactment of this section. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with relevant Federal agencies, States, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations, must submit a plan to Congress to enhance data matching for deceased individuals receiving federally funded benefits. An annual report on the implementation of this plan is also required for the next five years. The terms 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' are defined in section 4 of the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act (25 U.S.C. 450b). SEC. 4. PLAN FOR ENSURING THE ACCURACY AND COMPLETENESS OF DEATH DATA MAINTAINED BY THE SOCIAL SECURITY ADMINISTRATION. The Commissioner of Social Security, in consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, must submit a plan to Congress within 90 days of the enactment of this Act. The plan aims to ensure the accuracy and completeness of death data maintained by the Social Security Administration, including identifying errors in records of extremely elderly individuals and improving procedures for correcting inaccurate information. The plan required by the Act aims to improve the accuracy of death data maintained by the Social Security Administration through various measures, including identifying and correcting errors in records, employing statistical analysis, and making recommendations for legislation. The Commissioner of Social Security must implement this plan within 2 years of the Act's enactment.
